Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody and parenting-time orders may be modified where there has been a material change in circumstances since entry of the prior order and where the requested modification is in the best interests of the child.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, custody and parenting-time orders may be modified where there has been a material change in circumstances since entry of the prior order and where the requested modification is in the best interests of the child.

Massachusetts Rules of Domestic Relation.raw_text: Massachusetts Rules of Domestic Relations Procedure
Massachusetts Rules of Domestic Relation.proposition: Plaintiff relies upon the statutes and case law governing modification of custody and parenting-time orders and the best-interests standard, including but not limited to:

Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).raw_text: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (parental rights and deference to fit parenting decisions);
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (parental rights and deference to fit parenting decisions);
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: The plurality opinion squarely recognizes a fundamental liberty interest of parents in the care, custody, and control of their children and holds that courts must give “special weight” to the decisions of fit parents about third‑party visitation. It invalidates the Washington visitation order precisely because the trial court failed to accord deference to the fit mother’s judgment and instead substituted its own “best interests” view. Thus Troxel is direct authority for parental rights and required deference to fit parents’ decisions regarding their children.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “In light of this extensive precedent, it cannot now be doubted that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protects the fundamental right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children. … [S]o long as a parent adequately cares for his or her children (i. e., is fit), there will normally be no reason for the State to inject itself into the private realm of the family… And, if a fit parent's decision of the kind at issue here becomes subject to judicial review, the court must accord at least some special weight to the parent's own determination.”

Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).raw_text: Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982) (due process principles applicable to parental rights);
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).proposition: Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982) (due process principles applicable to parental rights);
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion directly holds that the Fourteenth Amendment’s Due Process Clause applies to state-initiated termination of parental rights and prescribes specific due process requirements, most notably a clear-and-convincing evidence standard. The Court extensively analyzes due process principles in the parental rights context using the Mathews v. Eldridge framework, confirming that termination proceedings must afford parents fundamentally fair procedures. This squarely supports the general proposition that Santosky is a leading case on due process principles applicable to parental rights.
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “Today we hold that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment demands more than this. Before a State may sever completely and irrevocably the rights of parents in their natural child, due process requires that the State support its allegations by at least clear and convincing evidence. … When the State moves to destroy weakened familial bonds, it must provide the parents with fundamentally fair procedures.”

Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972).raw_text: Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972) (parental rights precedent);
Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972).proposition: Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972) (parental rights precedent);
Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that an unwed father who has sired and raised his children has a constitutionally protected parental interest and cannot be deprived of custody without an individualized hearing on fitness. It grounds this in both due process (recognizing the fundamental interest in the care, custody, and management of one’s children) and equal protection (requiring the same procedural protections afforded other parents). Thus, it is a leading parental-rights precedent and supports the generic proposition for which it is cited.
Stanley v. Illinois, 405 U.S. 645 (1972).relevant_excerpt: “We conclude that, as a matter of due process of law, Stanley was entitled to a hearing on his fitness as a parent before his children were taken from him and that, by denying him a hearing and extending it to all other parents whose custody of their children is challenged, the State denied Stanley the equal protection of the laws guaranteed by the Fourteenth Amendment. … The private interest here, that of a man in the children he has sired and raised, undeniably warrants deference and, absent a powerful countervailing interest, protection.”
